ğŸ©º  Unlocking Healthcare Excellence in the Middle East: Top Destinations, Leading Doctors, and the Road Ahead (part 1)As the Middle East continues its rapid transformation, one sector rising to the forefront is healthcare. Over the last decade, weâ€™ve witnessed an incredible evolution- not just in infrastructure but in innovation, specialization, and global reputation. Countries across the region are now competing not only to serve their local populations but also to become global hubs for medical tourism.Hereâ€™s a look at where things stand, whoâ€™s leading the charge, and what opportunities lie ahead.ğŸ¥ Top Healthcare Destinations in the Middle East1. IranOften underrepresented in international rankings due to geopolitical factors, Iran is in fact one of the most advanced medical ecosystems in the region. With a high density of top-tier specialists, state-of-the-art surgical centers, and remarkably affordable pricing, Iran has become a go-to destination for patients from neighboring countries, Central Asia, and even Europe. From oncology and transplant surgery to fertility and reconstructive procedures, Iranian doctors are not only highly skilled but also often pioneers in their fields. Cities like Tehran, Shiraz, Mashhad, and Isfahan host globally respected hospitals and research institutions.2. United Arab Emirates (UAE)Dubai and Abu Dhabi have positioned themselves as world-class medical tourism destinations. With internationally accredited hospitals like Cleveland Clinic Abu Dhabi and Dubai Healthcare City, the UAE is attracting patients from across the GCC, Africa, and beyond.3. Saudi Arabia As part of Vision 2030, Saudi Arabia is heavily investing in transforming its healthcare sector. Riyadh and Jeddah now host a growing number of specialized hospitals, and the Kingdom is actively pursuing public-private partnerships (PPPs) to fast-track innovation and infrastructure.4. QatarHome to Sidra Medicine and Hamad Medical Corporation, Qatar is building a reputation for excellence in pediatric and women's health, with a strong focus on research and academic partnerships.5. Jordan and LebanonKnown for decades as go-to destinations for affordable, high-quality care, particularly in cardiology, oncology, and cosmetic procedures. These countries remain key players, especially for patients from North Africa and the Levant.hashtag#Healthcare hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#HealthTech hashtag#Investment hashtag#Innovation hashtag#DigitalHealth hashtag#Iran hashtag#UAE hashtag#Saudiarabia hashtag#Qatar hashtag#Jordan hashtag#Lebanon hashtag#doctor

Remember when setting up in a UAE Free Zone felt like unlocking a treasure chest of tax benefits? Well, the map has changed, and it's time to chart a new course.The UAE's new corporate tax regime is here, and while Free Zone businesses can still enjoy a 0% tax rate, it's not automatic. To qualify as a Qualifying Free Zone Person (QFZP), you need to meet specific criteria:âœ… Key Requirements:â€¢ Qualifying Income: Earn income from transactions with other Free Zone entities or from defined qualifying activities.â€¢ Substance Requirements: Maintain adequate physical presence and operations within the Free Zone.â€¢ De Minimis Rule: Ensure non-qualifying income doesn't exceed 5% of total revenue or AED 5 million, whichever is lower.â€¢ Audited Financials: Prepare and maintain audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS.âš  Consequences of Non-Compliance: Failing to meet these conditions means losing QFZP status and being subject to the standard 9% corporate tax rate for at least five years.ğŸ’¡ Take Action Now: Review your business activities, ensure compliance with the new regulations, and consult with tax professionals to navigate this transition smoothly.hashtag#UAE hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#FreeZone hashtag#BusinessStrategy hashtag#TaxCompliance hashtag#EconomicDiversification hashtag#TaxStrategy hashtag#QFZP hashtag#Brooksme

ğŸŒ KSAâ€™s New UBO Disclosure Rules â€“ Initial Observations ğŸŒ The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key featuresâ€”and notable sticking pointsâ€”of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰Â Only legal entitiesÂ incorporated in KSAÂ are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.ğŸ‘‰Â Important to note:Â Technically, the disclosure obligation doesÂ notÂ extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1ï¸âƒ£  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  â–ªï¸ â‰¥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  â–ªï¸ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entityâ€™s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2ï¸âƒ£ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to â€œinfluenceâ€ a KSA legal entityâ€™s operations or decisions.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œInfluenceâ€ is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰ Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of aÂ â€œlegal representativeâ€â€”even up through multiple levels.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œLegal representativeâ€ is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?â–ªï¸ At incorporationÂ for new entitiesâ–ªï¸ By the next commercial register anniversaryÂ for existing entitiesâš ï¸ Sticking point: There isÂ no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.ğŸ“Â Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. UAE Doubles Down on Global Education: $14.5B Deal with Nord Anglia Education Signals New Era in Talent Investment In April 2025, Mubadala Investment Company and Dubai Holding joined a global consortium to acquire Nord Anglia Education a premium international schools operator in a $14.5 billion megadeal, one of the largest education-focused acquisitions in history.The UAE is no longer just educating its youth itâ€™s investing in how the world learns.Whoâ€™s Involved in the $14.5B Consortium?1. EQT Group â€“ Europeâ€™s largest PE firm 2. Neuberger Berman 3. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments)4. CorporaciÃ³n Financiera Alba5. Mubadala Investment Company â€“ $600M stake (confirmed)6. Dubai Holding â€“ strategic investor (amount undisclosed)Why Mubadala Made This InvestmentMubadalaâ€™s $600M equity stake is not just capital deployment itâ€™s part of a national capability strategy:1. Human Capital First: Mubadala aligns with the UAEâ€™s vision that education is the cornerstone of national prosperity.2. Future Workforce Fit: Nord Angliaâ€™s AI, STEAM, and leadership programs are aligned with UAEâ€™s AI Strategy 2031 and Fourth Industrial Revolution goals.3. Global Returns, Local Impact: Investing in a global operator helps bring best practices to the UAE and generate returns that diversify away from oil.Why Dubai Holding Joined the DealDubai Holdingâ€™s participation is deeply strategic it goes beyond finance and reflects a long-term vision:1. City Branding: Dubai aims to be the #1 global city for living, working, and raising families. World-class education is central to that.2. Direct Ecosystem Benefit: Nord Anglia already operates two leading schools in Dubai. This investment strengthens Dubaiâ€™s appeal to global talent and companies.3. Soft Power Diplomacy: Enhancing Dubaiâ€™s presence in global education circles elevates its cultural and institutional reputation.Why Nord Anglia?1. 85,000+ students | 80+ campuses | 33 countries2. Over 50% of students enter Top 100 QS-ranked universities3. Strategic partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, UNICEF4. AI, coding, entrepreneurship integrated from early stages5. Flagships in: Dubai, Abu Dhabi, New York, Dublin, Hong Kong, GenevaThe UAEâ€™s Local Education Ecosystem:1. 827 international schools the largest per capita globally2. AED 26B ($7.1B): Projected UAE private K-12 market by 2027 3. 220+ international schools in Dubai alone4. 60,000+ new student seats added in 2 years5. 35% of UAE population is under 256. 89% expat population requires premium education options7. 40% of UAEâ€™s federal budget (2025) allocated to social development education is the top priorityThis investment future-proofs the economy, drives educational reform, and expands the nationâ€™s global influence in shaping knowledge ecosystems.This is how visionary nations invest not just in infrastructure but in intellect.

Post Content:
ğŸ©º  Unlocking Healthcare Excellence in the Middle East: Top Destinations, Leading Doctors, and the Road Ahead (part 1)As the Middle East continues its rapid transformation, one sector rising to the forefront is healthcare. Over the last decade, weâ€™ve witnessed an incredible evolution- not just in infrastructure but in innovation, specialization, and global reputation. Countries across the region are now competing not only to serve their local populations but also to become global hubs for medical tourism.Hereâ€™s a look at where things stand, whoâ€™s leading the charge, and what opportunities lie ahead.ğŸ¥ Top Healthcare Destinations in the Middle East1. IranOften underrepresented in international rankings due to geopolitical factors, Iran is in fact one of the most advanced medical ecosystems in the region. With a high density of top-tier specialists, state-of-the-art surgical centers, and remarkably affordable pricing, Iran has become a go-to destination for patients from neighboring countries, Central Asia, and even Europe. From oncology and transplant surgery to fertility and reconstructive procedures, Iranian doctors are not only highly skilled but also often pioneers in their fields. Cities like Tehran, Shiraz, Mashhad, and Isfahan host globally respected hospitals and research institutions.2. United Arab Emirates (UAE)Dubai and Abu Dhabi have positioned themselves as world-class medical tourism destinations. With internationally accredited hospitals like Cleveland Clinic Abu Dhabi and Dubai Healthcare City, the UAE is attracting patients from across the GCC, Africa, and beyond.3. Saudi Arabia As part of Vision 2030, Saudi Arabia is heavily investing in transforming its healthcare sector. Riyadh and Jeddah now host a growing number of specialized hospitals, and the Kingdom is actively pursuing public-private partnerships (PPPs) to fast-track innovation and infrastructure.4. QatarHome to Sidra Medicine and Hamad Medical Corporation, Qatar is building a reputation for excellence in pediatric and women's health, with a strong focus on research and academic partnerships.5. Remember when setting up in a UAE Free Zone felt like unlocking a treasure chest of tax benefits? Well, the map has changed, and it's time to chart a new course.The UAE's new corporate tax regime is here, and while Free Zone businesses can still enjoy a 0% tax rate, it's not automatic. To qualify as a Qualifying Free Zone Person (QFZP), you need to meet specific criteria:âœ… Key Requirements:â€¢ Qualifying Income: Earn income from transactions with other Free Zone entities or from defined qualifying activities.â€¢ Substance Requirements: Maintain adequate physical presence and operations within the Free Zone.â€¢ De Minimis Rule: Ensure non-qualifying income doesn't exceed 5% of total revenue or AED 5 million, whichever is lower.â€¢ Audited Financials: Prepare and maintain audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS.âš  Consequences of Non-Compliance: Failing to meet these conditions means losing QFZP status and being subject to the standard 9% corporate tax rate for at least five years.ğŸ’¡ Take Action Now: Review your business activities, ensure compliance with the new regulations, and consult with tax professionals to navigate this transition smoothly.hashtag#UAE hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#FreeZone hashtag#BusinessStrategy hashtag#TaxCompliance hashtag#EconomicDiversification hashtag#TaxStrategy hashtag#QFZP hashtag#Brooksme

The Finance Skills That Helped Me Thrive in Dubai and Will Matter Even More in 2025!When I first moved to Dubai, I thought technical knowledge alone would be enough.But I quickly realized: finance here isnâ€™t just about closing books. Itâ€™s about unlocking strategy, spotting trends, and speaking the language of business.And if I have to share 5 skillsets that are essential for a finance professional to be future-ready in the UAE market, they would be:1. Financial Modeling & Forecasting In a city where industries evolve overnight, static budgets donâ€™t cut it. You need models that breathe with the business.2. Data Analytics & Dashboarding (Power BI)Itâ€™s no longer about what happened. Stakeholders want to see why it happened, and that too visually, clearly, instantly.3. Automation & Process OptimizationTime is a premium. Automating even 10% of manual tasks can unlock hours for deeper, strategic work.4. ğŸŒ KSAâ€™s New UBO Disclosure Rules â€“ Initial Observations ğŸŒ The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key featuresâ€”and notable sticking pointsâ€”of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰Â Only legal entitiesÂ incorporated in KSAÂ are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.ğŸ‘‰Â Important to note:Â Technically, the disclosure obligation doesÂ notÂ extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1ï¸âƒ£  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  â–ªï¸ â‰¥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  â–ªï¸ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entityâ€™s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2ï¸âƒ£ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to â€œinfluenceâ€ a KSA legal entityâ€™s operations or decisions.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œInfluenceâ€ is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰ Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of aÂ â€œlegal representativeâ€â€”even up through multiple levels.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œLegal representativeâ€ is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?â–ªï¸ At incorporationÂ for new entitiesâ–ªï¸ By the next commercial register anniversaryÂ for existing entitiesâš ï¸ Sticking point: There isÂ no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.ğŸ“Â Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

EQT Group â€“ Europeâ€™s largest PE firm 2. Neuberger Berman 3. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments)4. CorporaciÃ³n Financiera Alba5. Mubadala Investment Company â€“ $600M stake (confirmed)6. Dubai Holding â€“ strategic investor (amount undisclosed)Why Mubadala Made This InvestmentMubadalaâ€™s $600M equity stake is not just capital deployment itâ€™s part of a national capability strategy:1. Human Capital First: Mubadala aligns with the UAEâ€™s vision that education is the cornerstone of national prosperity.2. Future Workforce Fit: Nord Angliaâ€™s AI, STEAM, and leadership programs are aligned with UAEâ€™s AI Strategy 2031 and Fourth Industrial Revolution goals.3. Global Returns, Local Impact: Investing in a global operator helps bring best practices to the UAE and generate returns that diversify away from oil.Why Dubai Holding Joined the DealDubai Holdingâ€™s participation is deeply strategic it goes beyond finance and reflects a long-term vision:1. City Branding: Dubai aims to be the #1 global city for living, working, and raising families. World-class education is central to that.2. Direct Ecosystem Benefit: Nord Anglia already operates two leading schools in Dubai. This investment strengthens Dubaiâ€™s appeal to global talent and companies.3. Soft Power Diplomacy: Enhancing Dubaiâ€™s presence in global education circles elevates its cultural and institutional reputation.Why Nord Anglia?1. 85,000+ students | 80+ campuses | 33 countries2. Over 50% of students enter Top 100 QS-ranked universities3. Strategic partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, UNICEF4. AI, coding, entrepreneurship integrated from early stages5. Flagships in: Dubai, Abu Dhabi, New York, Dublin, Hong Kong, GenevaThe UAEâ€™s Local Education Ecosystem:1. 827 international schools the largest per capita globally2. AED 26B ($7.1B): Projected UAE private K-12 market by 2027 3. 220+ international schools in Dubai alone4. 60,000+ new student seats added in 2 years5. 35% of UAE population is under 256. 89% expat population requires premium education options7. 40% of UAEâ€™s federal budget (2025) allocated to social development education is the top priorityThis investment future-proofs the economy, drives educational reform, and expands the nationâ€™s global influence in shaping knowledge ecosystems.This is how visionary nations invest not just in infrastructure but in intellect.

ğŸ©º  Unlocking Healthcare Excellence in the Middle East: Top Destinations, Leading Doctors, and the Road Ahead (part 1)As the Middle East continues its rapid transformation, one sector rising to the forefront is healthcare. Over the last decade, weâ€™ve witnessed an incredible evolution- not just in infrastructure but in innovation, specialization, and global reputation. Countries across the region are now competing not only to serve their local populations but also to become global hubs for medical tourism.Hereâ€™s a look at where things stand, whoâ€™s leading the charge, and what opportunities lie ahead.ğŸ¥ Top Healthcare Destinations in the Middle East1. IranOften underrepresented in international rankings due to geopolitical factors, Iran is in fact one of the most advanced medical ecosystems in the region. With a high density of top-tier specialists, state-of-the-art surgical centers, and remarkably affordable pricing, Iran has become a go-to destination for patients from neighboring countries, Central Asia, and even Europe. From oncology and transplant surgery to fertility and reconstructive procedures, Iranian doctors are not only highly skilled but also often pioneers in their fields. Cities like Tehran, Shiraz, Mashhad, and Isfahan host globally respected hospitals and research institutions.2. United Arab Emirates (UAE)Dubai and Abu Dhabi have positioned themselves as world-class medical tourism destinations. With internationally accredited hospitals like Cleveland Clinic Abu Dhabi and Dubai Healthcare City, the UAE is attracting patients from across the GCC, Africa, and beyond.3. Saudi Arabia As part of Vision 2030, Saudi Arabia is heavily investing in transforming its healthcare sector. Riyadh and Jeddah now host a growing number of specialized hospitals, and the Kingdom is actively pursuing public-private partnerships (PPPs) to fast-track innovation and infrastructure.4. QatarHome to Sidra Medicine and Hamad Medical Corporation, Qatar is building a reputation for excellence in pediatric and women's health, with a strong focus on research and academic partnerships.5. Jordan and LebanonKnown for decades as go-to destinations for affordable, high-quality care, particularly in cardiology, oncology, and cosmetic procedures. These countries remain key players, especially for patients from North Africa and the Levant.hashtag#Healthcare hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#HealthTech hashtag#Investment hashtag#Innovation hashtag#DigitalHealth hashtag#Iran hashtag#UAE hashtag#Saudiarabia hashtag#Qatar hashtag#Jordan hashtag#Lebanon hashtag#doctor

Remember when setting up in a UAE Free Zone felt like unlocking a treasure chest of tax benefits? Well, the map has changed, and it's time to chart a new course.The UAE's new corporate tax regime is here, and while Free Zone businesses can still enjoy a 0% tax rate, it's not automatic. To qualify as a Qualifying Free Zone Person (QFZP), you need to meet specific criteria:âœ… Key Requirements:â€¢ Qualifying Income: Earn income from transactions with other Free Zone entities or from defined qualifying activities.â€¢ Substance Requirements: Maintain adequate physical presence and operations within the Free Zone.â€¢ De Minimis Rule: Ensure non-qualifying income doesn't exceed 5% of total revenue or AED 5 million, whichever is lower.â€¢ Audited Financials: Prepare and maintain audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS.âš  Consequences of Non-Compliance: Failing to meet these conditions means losing QFZP status and being subject to the standard 9% corporate tax rate for at least five years.ğŸ’¡ Take Action Now: Review your business activities, ensure compliance with the new regulations, and consult with tax professionals to navigate this transition smoothly.hashtag#UAE hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#FreeZone hashtag#BusinessStrategy hashtag#TaxCompliance hashtag#EconomicDiversification hashtag#TaxStrategy hashtag#QFZP hashtag#Brooksme

ğŸŒ KSAâ€™s New UBO Disclosure Rules â€“ Initial Observations ğŸŒ The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key featuresâ€”and notable sticking pointsâ€”of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰Â Only legal entitiesÂ incorporated in KSAÂ are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.ğŸ‘‰Â Important to note:Â Technically, the disclosure obligation doesÂ notÂ extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1ï¸âƒ£  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  â–ªï¸ â‰¥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  â–ªï¸ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entityâ€™s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2ï¸âƒ£ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to â€œinfluenceâ€ a KSA legal entityâ€™s operations or decisions.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œInfluenceâ€ is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰ Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of aÂ â€œlegal representativeâ€â€”even up through multiple levels.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œLegal representativeâ€ is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?â–ªï¸ At incorporationÂ for new entitiesâ–ªï¸ By the next commercial register anniversaryÂ for existing entitiesâš ï¸ Sticking point: There isÂ no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.ğŸ“Â Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

UAE Doubles Down on Global Education: $14.5B Deal with Nord Anglia Education Signals New Era in Talent Investment In April 2025, Mubadala Investment Company and Dubai Holding joined a global consortium to acquire Nord Anglia Education a premium international schools operator in a $14.5 billion megadeal, one of the largest education-focused acquisitions in history.The UAE is no longer just educating its youth itâ€™s investing in how the world learns.Whoâ€™s Involved in the $14.5B Consortium?1. EQT Group â€“ Europeâ€™s largest PE firm 2. Neuberger Berman 3. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments)4. CorporaciÃ³n Financiera Alba5. Mubadala Investment Company â€“ $600M stake (confirmed)6. Dubai Holding â€“ strategic investor (amount undisclosed)Why Mubadala Made This InvestmentMubadalaâ€™s $600M equity stake is not just capital deployment itâ€™s part of a national capability strategy:1. Human Capital First: Mubadala aligns with the UAEâ€™s vision that education is the cornerstone of national prosperity.2. Future Workforce Fit: Nord Angliaâ€™s AI, STEAM, and leadership programs are aligned with UAEâ€™s AI Strategy 2031 and Fourth Industrial Revolution goals.3. Global Returns, Local Impact: Investing in a global operator helps bring best practices to the UAE and generate returns that diversify away from oil.Why Dubai Holding Joined the DealDubai Holdingâ€™s participation is deeply strategic it goes beyond finance and reflects a long-term vision:1. City Branding: Dubai aims to be the #1 global city for living, working, and raising families. World-class education is central to that.2. Direct Ecosystem Benefit: Nord Anglia already operates two leading schools in Dubai. This investment strengthens Dubaiâ€™s appeal to global talent and companies.3. Soft Power Diplomacy: Enhancing Dubaiâ€™s presence in global education circles elevates its cultural and institutional reputation.Why Nord Anglia?1. 85,000+ students | 80+ campuses | 33 countries2. Over 50% of students enter Top 100 QS-ranked universities3. Strategic partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, UNICEF4. AI, coding, entrepreneurship integrated from early stages5. Flagships in: Dubai, Abu Dhabi, New York, Dublin, Hong Kong, GenevaThe UAEâ€™s Local Education Ecosystem:1. 827 international schools the largest per capita globally2. AED 26B ($7.1B): Projected UAE private K-12 market by 2027 3. 220+ international schools in Dubai alone4. 60,000+ new student seats added in 2 years5. 35% of UAE population is under 256. 89% expat population requires premium education options7. 40% of UAEâ€™s federal budget (2025) allocated to social development education is the top priorityThis investment future-proofs the economy, drives educational reform, and expands the nationâ€™s global influence in shaping knowledge ecosystems.This is how visionary nations invest not just in infrastructure but in intellect.

ğŸ©º  Unlocking Healthcare Excellence in the Middle East: Top Destinations, Leading Doctors, and the Road Ahead (part 1)As the Middle East continues its rapid transformation, one sector rising to the forefront is healthcare. Over the last decade, weâ€™ve witnessed an incredible evolution- not just in infrastructure but in innovation, specialization, and global reputation. Countries across the region are now competing not only to serve their local populations but also to become global hubs for medical tourism.Hereâ€™s a look at where things stand, whoâ€™s leading the charge, and what opportunities lie ahead.ğŸ¥ Top Healthcare Destinations in the Middle East1. IranOften underrepresented in international rankings due to geopolitical factors, Iran is in fact one of the most advanced medical ecosystems in the region. With a high density of top-tier specialists, state-of-the-art surgical centers, and remarkably affordable pricing, Iran has become a go-to destination for patients from neighboring countries, Central Asia, and even Europe. From oncology and transplant surgery to fertility and reconstructive procedures, Iranian doctors are not only highly skilled but also often pioneers in their fields. Cities like Tehran, Shiraz, Mashhad, and Isfahan host globally respected hospitals and research institutions.2. United Arab Emirates (UAE)Dubai and Abu Dhabi have positioned themselves as world-class medical tourism destinations. With internationally accredited hospitals like Cleveland Clinic Abu Dhabi and Dubai Healthcare City, the UAE is attracting patients from across the GCC, Africa, and beyond.3. Saudi Arabia As part of Vision 2030, Saudi Arabia is heavily investing in transforming its healthcare sector. Riyadh and Jeddah now host a growing number of specialized hospitals, and the Kingdom is actively pursuing public-private partnerships (PPPs) to fast-track innovation and infrastructure.4. QatarHome to Sidra Medicine and Hamad Medical Corporation, Qatar is building a reputation for excellence in pediatric and women's health, with a strong focus on research and academic partnerships.5. Jordan and LebanonKnown for decades as go-to destinations for affordable, high-quality care, particularly in cardiology, oncology, and cosmetic procedures. These countries remain key players, especially for patients from North Africa and the Levant.hashtag#Healthcare hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#HealthTech hashtag#Investment hashtag#Innovation hashtag#DigitalHealth hashtag#Iran hashtag#UAE hashtag#Saudiarabia hashtag#Qatar hashtag#Jordan hashtag#Lebanon hashtag#doctor

Remember when setting up in a UAE Free Zone felt like unlocking a treasure chest of tax benefits? Well, the map has changed, and it's time to chart a new course.The UAE's new corporate tax regime is here, and while Free Zone businesses can still enjoy a 0% tax rate, it's not automatic. To qualify as a Qualifying Free Zone Person (QFZP), you need to meet specific criteria:âœ… Key Requirements:â€¢ Qualifying Income: Earn income from transactions with other Free Zone entities or from defined qualifying activities.â€¢ Substance Requirements: Maintain adequate physical presence and operations within the Free Zone.â€¢ De Minimis Rule: Ensure non-qualifying income doesn't exceed 5% of total revenue or AED 5 million, whichever is lower.â€¢ Audited Financials: Prepare and maintain audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS.âš  Consequences of Non-Compliance: Failing to meet these conditions means losing QFZP status and being subject to the standard 9% corporate tax rate for at least five years.ğŸ’¡ Take Action Now: Review your business activities, ensure compliance with the new regulations, and consult with tax professionals to navigate this transition smoothly.hashtag#UAE hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#FreeZone hashtag#BusinessStrategy hashtag#TaxCompliance hashtag#EconomicDiversification hashtag#TaxStrategy hashtag#QFZP hashtag#Brooksme

ğŸŒ KSAâ€™s New UBO Disclosure Rules â€“ Initial Observations ğŸŒ The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key featuresâ€”and notable sticking pointsâ€”of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰Â Only legal entitiesÂ incorporated in KSAÂ are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.ğŸ‘‰Â Important to note:Â Technically, the disclosure obligation doesÂ notÂ extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1ï¸âƒ£  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  â–ªï¸ â‰¥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  â–ªï¸ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entityâ€™s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2ï¸âƒ£ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to â€œinfluenceâ€ a KSA legal entityâ€™s operations or decisions.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œInfluenceâ€ is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰ Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of aÂ â€œlegal representativeâ€â€”even up through multiple levels.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œLegal representativeâ€ is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?â–ªï¸ At incorporationÂ for new entitiesâ–ªï¸ By the next commercial register anniversaryÂ for existing entitiesâš ï¸ Sticking point: There isÂ no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.ğŸ“Â Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

UAE Doubles Down on Global Education: $14.5B Deal with Nord Anglia Education Signals New Era in Talent Investment In April 2025, Mubadala Investment Company and Dubai Holding joined a global consortium to acquire Nord Anglia Education a premium international schools operator in a $14.5 billion megadeal, one of the largest education-focused acquisitions in history.The UAE is no longer just educating its youth itâ€™s investing in how the world learns.Whoâ€™s Involved in the $14.5B Consortium?1. EQT Group â€“ Europeâ€™s largest PE firm 2. Neuberger Berman 3. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments)4. CorporaciÃ³n Financiera Alba5. Mubadala Investment Company â€“ $600M stake (confirmed)6. Dubai Holding â€“ strategic investor (amount undisclosed)Why Mubadala Made This InvestmentMubadalaâ€™s $600M equity stake is not just capital deployment itâ€™s part of a national capability strategy:1. Human Capital First: Mubadala aligns with the UAEâ€™s vision that education is the cornerstone of national prosperity.2. Future Workforce Fit: Nord Angliaâ€™s AI, STEAM, and leadership programs are aligned with UAEâ€™s AI Strategy 2031 and Fourth Industrial Revolution goals.3. Global Returns, Local Impact: Investing in a global operator helps bring best practices to the UAE and generate returns that diversify away from oil.Why Dubai Holding Joined the DealDubai Holdingâ€™s participation is deeply strategic it goes beyond finance and reflects a long-term vision:1. City Branding: Dubai aims to be the #1 global city for living, working, and raising families. World-class education is central to that.2. Direct Ecosystem Benefit: Nord Anglia already operates two leading schools in Dubai. This investment strengthens Dubaiâ€™s appeal to global talent and companies.3. Soft Power Diplomacy: Enhancing Dubaiâ€™s presence in global education circles elevates its cultural and institutional reputation.Why Nord Anglia?1. 85,000+ students | 80+ campuses | 33 countries2. Over 50% of students enter Top 100 QS-ranked universities3. Strategic partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, UNICEF4. AI, coding, entrepreneurship integrated from early stages5. Flagships in: Dubai, Abu Dhabi, New York, Dublin, Hong Kong, GenevaThe UAEâ€™s Local Education Ecosystem:1. 827 international schools the largest per capita globally2. AED 26B ($7.1B): Projected UAE private K-12 market by 2027 3. 220+ international schools in Dubai alone4. 60,000+ new student seats added in 2 years5. 35% of UAE population is under 256. 89% expat population requires premium education options7. 40% of UAEâ€™s federal budget (2025) allocated to social development education is the top priorityThis investment future-proofs the economy, drives educational reform, and expands the nationâ€™s global influence in shaping knowledge ecosystems.This is how visionary nations invest not just in infrastructure but in intellect.

ğŸ©º  Unlocking Healthcare Excellence in the Middle East: Top Destinations, Leading Doctors, and the Road Ahead (part 1)As the Middle East continues its rapid transformation, one sector rising to the forefront is healthcare. Over the last decade, weâ€™ve witnessed an incredible evolution- not just in infrastructure but in innovation, specialization, and global reputation. Countries across the region are now competing not only to serve their local populations but also to become global hubs for medical tourism.Hereâ€™s a look at where things stand, whoâ€™s leading the charge, and what opportunities lie ahead.ğŸ¥ Top Healthcare Destinations in the Middle East1. IranOften underrepresented in international rankings due to geopolitical factors, Iran is in fact one of the most advanced medical ecosystems in the region. With a high density of top-tier specialists, state-of-the-art surgical centers, and remarkably affordable pricing, Iran has become a go-to destination for patients from neighboring countries, Central Asia, and even Europe. From oncology and transplant surgery to fertility and reconstructive procedures, Iranian doctors are not only highly skilled but also often pioneers in their fields. Cities like Tehran, Shiraz, Mashhad, and Isfahan host globally respected hospitals and research institutions.2. United Arab Emirates (UAE)Dubai and Abu Dhabi have positioned themselves as world-class medical tourism destinations. With internationally accredited hospitals like Cleveland Clinic Abu Dhabi and Dubai Healthcare City, the UAE is attracting patients from across the GCC, Africa, and beyond.3. Saudi Arabia As part of Vision 2030, Saudi Arabia is heavily investing in transforming its healthcare sector. Riyadh and Jeddah now host a growing number of specialized hospitals, and the Kingdom is actively pursuing public-private partnerships (PPPs) to fast-track innovation and infrastructure.4. QatarHome to Sidra Medicine and Hamad Medical Corporation, Qatar is building a reputation for excellence in pediatric and women's health, with a strong focus on research and academic partnerships.5. Jordan and LebanonKnown for decades as go-to destinations for affordable, high-quality care, particularly in cardiology, oncology, and cosmetic procedures. These countries remain key players, especially for patients from North Africa and the Levant.hashtag#Healthcare hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#HealthTech hashtag#Investment hashtag#Innovation hashtag#DigitalHealth hashtag#Iran hashtag#UAE hashtag#Saudiarabia hashtag#Qatar hashtag#Jordan hashtag#Lebanon hashtag#doctor

Remember when setting up in a UAE Free Zone felt like unlocking a treasure chest of tax benefits? Well, the map has changed, and it's time to chart a new course.The UAE's new corporate tax regime is here, and while Free Zone businesses can still enjoy a 0% tax rate, it's not automatic. To qualify as a Qualifying Free Zone Person (QFZP), you need to meet specific criteria:âœ… Key Requirements:â€¢ Qualifying Income: Earn income from transactions with other Free Zone entities or from defined qualifying activities.â€¢ Substance Requirements: Maintain adequate physical presence and operations within the Free Zone.â€¢ De Minimis Rule: Ensure non-qualifying income doesn't exceed 5% of total revenue or AED 5 million, whichever is lower.â€¢ Audited Financials: Prepare and maintain audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS.âš  Consequences of Non-Compliance: Failing to meet these conditions means losing QFZP status and being subject to the standard 9% corporate tax rate for at least five years.ğŸ’¡ Take Action Now: Review your business activities, ensure compliance with the new regulations, and consult with tax professionals to navigate this transition smoothly.hashtag#UAE hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#FreeZone hashtag#BusinessStrategy hashtag#TaxCompliance hashtag#EconomicDiversification hashtag#TaxStrategy hashtag#QFZP hashtag#Brooksme

ğŸŒ KSAâ€™s New UBO Disclosure Rules â€“ Initial Observations ğŸŒ The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key featuresâ€”and notable sticking pointsâ€”of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰Â Only legal entitiesÂ incorporated in KSAÂ are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.ğŸ‘‰Â Important to note:Â Technically, the disclosure obligation doesÂ notÂ extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1ï¸âƒ£  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  â–ªï¸ â‰¥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  â–ªï¸ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entityâ€™s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2ï¸âƒ£ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to â€œinfluenceâ€ a KSA legal entityâ€™s operations or decisions.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œInfluenceâ€ is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?ğŸ‘‰ Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of aÂ â€œlegal representativeâ€â€”even up through multiple levels.âš ï¸Â Sticking point:Â â€œLegal representativeâ€ is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?â–ªï¸ At incorporationÂ for new entitiesâ–ªï¸ By the next commercial register anniversaryÂ for existing entitiesâš ï¸ Sticking point: There isÂ no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.ğŸ“Â Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

ğŸ©º  Unlocking Healthcare Excellence in the Middle East: Top Destinations, Leading Doctors, and the Road Ahead (part 1)As the Middle East continues its rapid transformation, one sector rising to the forefront is healthcare. Over the last decade, weâ€™ve witnessed an incredible evolution- not just in infrastructure but in innovation, specialization, and global reputation. Countries across the region are now competing not only to serve their local populations but also to become global hubs for medical tourism.Hereâ€™s a look at where things stand, whoâ€™s leading the charge, and what opportunities lie ahead.ğŸ¥ Top Healthcare Destinations in the Middle East1. IranOften underrepresented in international rankings due to geopolitical factors, Iran is in fact one of the most advanced medical ecosystems in the region. With a high density of top-tier specialists, state-of-the-art surgical centers, and remarkably affordable pricing, Iran has become a go-to destination for patients from neighboring countries, Central Asia, and even Europe. From oncology and transplant surgery to fertility and reconstructive procedures, Iranian doctors are not only highly skilled but also often pioneers in their fields. Cities like Tehran, Shiraz, Mashhad, and Isfahan host globally respected hospitals and research institutions.2. United Arab Emirates (UAE)Dubai and Abu Dhabi have positioned themselves as world-class medical tourism destinations. With internationally accredited hospitals like Cleveland Clinic Abu Dhabi and Dubai Healthcare City, the UAE is attracting patients from across the GCC, Africa, and beyond.3. Saudi Arabia As part of Vision 2030, Saudi Arabia is heavily investing in transforming its healthcare sector. Riyadh and Jeddah now host a growing number of specialized hospitals, and the Kingdom is actively pursuing public-private partnerships (PPPs) to fast-track innovation and infrastructure.4. QatarHome to Sidra Medicine and Hamad Medical Corporation, Qatar is building a reputation for excellence in pediatric and women's health, with a strong focus on research and academic partnerships.5. Jordan and LebanonKnown for decades as go-to destinations for affordable, high-quality care, particularly in cardiology, oncology, and cosmetic procedures. These countries remain key players, especially for patients from North Africa and the Levant.hashtag#Healthcare hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#HealthTech hashtag#Investment hashtag#Innovation hashtag#DigitalHealth hashtag#Iran hashtag#UAE hashtag#Saudiarabia hashtag#Qatar hashtag#Jordan hashtag#Lebanon hashtag#doctor

Remember when setting up in a UAE Free Zone felt like unlocking a treasure chest of tax benefits? Well, the map has changed, and it's time to chart a new course.The UAE's new corporate tax regime is here, and while Free Zone businesses can still enjoy a 0% tax rate, it's not automatic. To qualify as a Qualifying Free Zone Person (QFZP), you need to meet specific criteria:âœ… Key Requirements:â€¢ Qualifying Income: Earn income from transactions with other Free Zone entities or from defined qualifying activities.â€¢ Substance Requirements: Maintain adequate physical presence and operations within the Free Zone.â€¢ De Minimis Rule: Ensure non-qualifying income doesn't exceed 5% of total revenue or AED 5 million, whichever is lower.â€¢ Audited Financials: Prepare and maintain audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS.âš  Consequences of Non-Compliance: Failing to meet these conditions means losing QFZP status and being subject to the standard 9% corporate tax rate for at least five years.ğŸ’¡ Take Action Now: Review your business activities, ensure compliance with the new regulations, and consult with tax professionals to navigate this transition smoothly.hashtag#UAE hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#FreeZone hashtag#BusinessStrategy hashtag#TaxCompliance hashtag#EconomicDiversification hashtag#TaxStrategy hashtag#QFZP hashtag#Brooksme
